author: aperon
title: Global Cannabis Listing Platform
description: Licensed operators (buyers/sellers) of cannabis and hemp do not have a reliable consolidated marketplace to connect & regularly complete transactions efficiently with a high level of trust.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal has a clear problem statement that is aligned with the challenge. The impact of this global cannabis market running on Cardano could have a significant impact on the cannabis industry and Cardano. The cannabis industry has been projected to grow to 350 billion by 2030 https://cannabishealthnews.co.uk/2020/11/06/global-cannabis-industry-worth-350-billion-by-2030/ and we have seen the popularity among cardano holders with the rise of the "Cardano stoners club" on twitter, and Snoop Dog working on "Baked Nation" with the Claymates, and countless other cannabis related NFT projects. This marketplace could also help to bring new users and spread awareness of Cardano to Millions of cannabis users worldwide. If this Aperon venture is successful it could scale significantly bringing large volumes of transactions on to the cardano blockchain.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposing team has extensive experience in the cannabis industry and a proven business model that has been successful. They have provided details of the teams qualifications, and also hired an experienced Haskell dev who is a former IOHK engineer to complete the development work. https://www.linkedin.com/in/jann-m%C3%BCller/  The plan is detailed and broken down with key milestones listed and a timeline for each task. They have included significant flexibility for the time of each task with a total between 15 and 36 weeks. However considering the scope of this project this is reasonable as precise timelines are difficult to predict with so many interdependencies.  The proposal has included 5 perceived risk categories and provided detailed mitigation strategies for each.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal has a roadmap with key milestones and timelines. The work items or deliverables are clear, and the team has committed to the following in addition to internal reporting: "We will integrate these updates within Catalyst progress reporting. Links to Test sites can be made available to Challenge team members, as they are ready. We expect to be active in after town hall breakout meetings (main and Pacific) and swarm sessions where we can discuss progress, solicit ideas and answer community questions. I have given 4/5 stars for auditability because this is slightly vague about exactly what will be reported, where and when. I would like to see more specific detailed commitment to provide monthly reporting to the catalyst community and the proposal could include what metrics will be in the progress reports, when they will be published, and where they can be accessed.

f6_assessments.q0: I agree with the impact of this project. The problem statement is straightforward, and the proposer points out that the cannabis market is sizable ($80 billion globally) and growing. This use case meets one of Fund9's goals to build a real-world solution on Cardano.  However, I am unsure to what degree this product is a Decentralized App (DApp). The business model looks to me as a centralized solution belonging to the proposer's cannabis group of companies. It was not mentioned in the proposal if the users of this CLP will need to have a Cardano wallet to use the marketplace. It sounds like the Cardano blockchain will function as the backend and the frontend users do not need to onboard to the Cardano system to use it.  It may not be that the information provided is not sufficient to assess its impact on the Cardano ecosystem, and I would recommend the proposer to further elaborate on this front. The risks and mitigation section should be tailored for this specific product (i.e., the risks to implementing a marketplace should not be completely the same as the risks to building a supply chain tracking or grading app).
f6_assessments.q1: [My comment here has overlapped content with my comments for the other two proposals in Fund9 from the same proposer since those proposals share a large portion of content]  I agree that this proposal is feasible. The proposer presents in great detail the customer personas, their needs, the user stories, and the acceptance criteria for the system design. Similarly, the proposer plans a detailed timeline and milestones (I like that the minimum and maximum time estimations were given for each workstream. It makes it easier for the project team to keep track during implementation and for the community to verify it along the way). Given that the implementation plan is for all three proposals in Fund9, I would suggest the proposer provide one more level of implementation concerning each individual proposal of the three ones in Fund9. For example, the implementation plan and technical requirements to build this grading app must be different from those to build the marketplace. The budget breakdown is well thought through as well, as it is broken down by components and functions for all three proposals in Fund9 that the proposer has. It gives the community an overall view of the time budget for all three projects, and the specific budget for this proposal. The only concern I have for the budget is the high daily rate across the board. The budget specifies $1100/ 8-hour workday for the Plutus developer, this is on the high end in comparison to other proposals I have assessed. Or Project manager cost $260 per 2-hour workday, equivalent to $130/hour or $22,900 per month; this is a very high salary for a project manager when I compare it to the same role in the traditional tech industry in the US or in the blockchain. I would recommend the proposer revise this part of the budget. The team has experience in the cannabis industry and system architecture, though the Plutus developer is a contractor that may present some uncertainty.
f6_assessments.q2: [My comment here has overlapped content with my comments for the other two proposals in Fund9 from the same proposer since those proposals have similar shortfalls] The project is auditable from the perspective of product completion, but it is not so clear from the perspective of impact to the Cardano ecosystem. The KPIs proposed in the "How success looks like" section are all relevant to the product functions. As it has not been made clear how this product would bring a quantifiable positive impact to the Cardano community, I would recommend the proposal to add quantitative KPIs and metrics that are relevant to adoption or transactions on the Cardano blockchain. The roadmap with milestones for each individual proposal of the three ones could also be more elaborated for the community to track alongside the progress, and I suggest using a GANNT chart to do so.

f6_assessments.q1:

It’s safe to say, that they have an experienced team in the related fields & specifications needed to further support the project development. 

The goal set is feasible. The roadmap and key milestones provided are quite detailed & straightforward. f6_assessments.q2: The team provides multiple links to track their progress: through the website and other communication channels (Slack, Discord, Telegram, and WhatsApp), they also committed to providing weekly reviews and monthly progress reports. f6_assessments.q0: The cannabis industry is a very relevant and big industry with a very dedicated community. However, it is still a little difficult to find reputable sellers that deliver quality product. These sellers are even scarcer online, and on the blockchain. This proposal is very relevant to the current trends. The author already has an established brand and reputation in the cannabis world, which will help make the purchasing and the industry in general more secure, transparent, and of higher quality. The author also proposes ways to trace and grade cannabis sales and sellers, which will be invaluable in making the market more accessible. This proposal answers the challenge perfectly, in providing a better alternative than centralized options.
f6_assessments.q1: The author offers an incredibly detailed breakdown of the workload needed to accomplish this project. They seem very detail-oriented and organized, and the goals listed are reasonable and manageable. Similarly, the budget breakdown is very clear and concise, and the alloted funds are well thought-through. The leading team has extensive experience in both the cannabis industry and the cardano community. I believe they will have no technical issues in delivering this project. As for user adoption of this service, I believe it will know success, as the team leaders already have a large consumer base from their existing cannabis business. They have a real-life foundation. I believe this will bring them success. All in all, i have very high hopes for the success of this proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: The author offers a very detailed plan with clear deliverables, so there will be no problems tracking the progress. As the proposal has shown the author to be very detail-oriented, I believe the reports the author will offer will be very insightful to undersanding and tracking the development process. In addition to this, the author also offers weekly reports, and QnAs with comunity members through their chat platforms (discord, telegram..).

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal has a unique objective, trying to build a new Cannabis Listing Service (CLS) on the Cardano blockchain. The list containing quality-verified listings will then be accessible to buyers, brokers, sellers & 3rd parties globally. By this objective, a whole new ecosystem for Cannabis market will be created, thus more people would gather and use Cardano blockchain network on its transaction or information access regarding Cannabis, resulting in immense potential of increase in Cardano blockchain value. This visionary objective is also supported on the fact of how big and wide the market of Cannabis currently exist globally, and with the additional support on its listing with high-end tech like blockchain, the business will enter a new chapter of improvement, making it improving even further. The proposal has been written comprehensively with a very detailed and thorough plan, including the risk and its mitigations plan has also been specified.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal has defined the complete recap of action items and the timeline of their project in a quite precise measure, including the minimum and maximum visible time to make it done, resulting in more auditability and detailed time planning. Budget breakdown has also been detailed on which component it will cost (since many components are being integrated), and how many much cost-per-hour will be paid. The number of manpower is not really specified, since it is on the format of “teams”, yet what teams will be contributing has been explained clearly with their own tasks. Proposers’ background, experience, and relevant projects has also been included, making the project even more feasible measuring from their experience. LinkedIn profiles are included too for background checking.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposers have defined a clear key metrics as measurement of their success, such as the complete working platform and service, data integration and usage of marketplaces, new suppliers and new users, and etc. These metrics will then be measured and reported on weekly sprint reviews and monthly progress reports from the developers, integrated with Catalyst for their updates. They also mentioned about test sites that will be provided to Challenge team, which will also be another measurement of their progress. It is also mentioned that the progress will be updated in the Townhall and swarm session.
